Displacement Current is the current produced due to a changing electric field or electric flux ($\Phi_E$).
It is the term Maxwell added to Ampère's circuital law.
Formula: $I_d = \epsilon_0 \frac{d\Phi_E}{dt}$

The line integral of the magnetic field ($\mathbf{B}$) around any closed loop is proportional to the sum of the conduction current ($I_c$) and the displacement current ($I_d$).
\[ \oint \mathbf{B} \cdot d\mathbf{l} = \mu_0 I_c + \mu_0 \epsilon_0 \frac{d\Phi_E}{dt} \]

EM Waves are waves that propagate due to mutually perpendicular, time-varying electric fields ($\mathbf{E}$) and magnetic fields ($\mathbf{B}$).
They are transverse in nature and do not require a material medium to travel.

q: What is the source of Electromagnetic Waves?
a: EM waves are produced by accelerated charges (charges undergoing non-zero acceleration) or oscillating charges.

q: What is the speed of EM waves in a vacuum?
a:
The speed of EM waves in a vacuum is the speed of light ($c$).
Formula: \[ c = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_0 \epsilon_0}} \approx 3 \times 10^8 \text{ m/s} \]

q: What is the relation between the peak values of the Electric Field ($E_0$) and Magnetic Field ($B_0$) in an EM wave?
a:
The ratio of the peak electric field to the peak magnetic field equals the speed of light in a vacuum.
\[ c = \frac{E_0}{B_0} \]

q: In which direction does the EM Wave propagate?
a:
The EM wave propagates in the direction of the vector cross product of the electric and magnetic fields.
Propagation direction is parallel to $\mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B}$.

q: What is the formula for the Energy Density ($u$) of an EM wave?
a:
The energy density is equally shared between the electric and magnetic fields:
Total Energy Density: $u = u_E + u_B$
$$ u_E = \frac{1}{2} \epsilon_0 E^2 \quad \text{and} \quad u_B = \frac{1}{2\mu_0} B^2 $$

q: How do EM Waves transport energy and momentum?
a:
EM Waves transport energy (as both electric and magnetic energy densities) and momentum ($p$).
If the total energy transmitted is $U$, the momentum transferred is $p = U/c$.
When an EM wave falls on a surface, it exerts a force due to the momentum transfer. The force per unit area is called Radiation Pressure.

q: List the seven regions of the Electromagnetic Spectrum in increasing order of frequency.
Which part of the spectrum has the highest energy and the shortest wavelength?
a:
Gamma rays ($\gamma$-rays).
Energy ($E$) is directly proportional to frequency ($f$): $E = hf$.
Wavelength ($\lambda$) is inversely proportional to frequency: $f = c/\lambda$.

q: Give the approximate frequency range and two uses for Radio Waves.
a:
Range: $500 \text{ kHz}$ to $1000 \text{ MHz}$ (approx.)
Uses: Radio and Television communication (AM/FM, UHF/VHF bands).

q: Give the approximate frequency range and two uses for Microwaves.
a:
Range: $1 \text{ GHz}$ to $300 \text{ GHz}$ (approx.)
Uses: Microwave Ovens (cooking) and Radar systems.

q: Give the approximate frequency range and two uses for Infrared (IR) Waves.
a:
Range: $3 \times 10^{11} \text{ Hz}$ to $4 \times 10^{14} \text{ Hz}$ (approx.)
Uses: Thermal imaging (night vision) and Remote controls.

q: Give the approximate wavelength range and two uses for Visible Light.
a:
Range: $400 \text{ nm}$ to $700 \text{ nm}$ (approx.)
Uses: Human vision and Optical fibers (communication).

q: Give the approximate frequency range and two uses for Ultraviolet (UV) Waves.
a:
Range: $8 \times 10^{14} \text{ Hz}$ to $3 \times 10^{16} \text{ Hz}$ (approx.)
Uses: Sterilization (killing germs) and LASIK eye surgery.

q: Give the approximate frequency range and two uses for X-rays.
a:
Range: $3 \times 10^{16} \text{ Hz}$ to $3 \times 10^{19} \text{ Hz}$ (approx.)
Uses: Medical imaging (broken bones) and Crystallography (structure analysis).

q: Give the approximate frequency range and two uses for Gamma Rays ($\gamma$-rays).
a:
Range: $> 3 \times 10^{19} \text{ Hz}$ (approx.)
Uses: Cancer treatment (radiotherapy) and Sterilization of medical equipment.
